sd1_observation: There are many areas throughout the site including roads / footways which have thier finished surfaces near complete but have areas where patches are incomplete leaving trip & fall hazards with no barriers / cones etc observed.
sd1_potential_risk: Trip & Falls leading to personal injury, potential fractures and RIDDOR reportable incidents.
sd1_action: John Sisk & Sons Ltd and thier appointed sub-contractors must ensure that where these hazards are created, they exclude the hazard by establishing barriers.

sd1_observation: The Construction Phase Plan was being reveiewed by the WSP Site Engineer (Ian Smith) although no comments have been forwarded to date. Any actions will therefore be led by Ian Smith and are not included in this report.
Bottles/cylindaers were noted stored upright, in cages and suitably signed.
Both compound and on-site storage facilities were deemed to be adequate at the time of the visit and no issued were observed.
Operatives from P&T Contracts observed using a powercap to remove the risk of inhaling silica dust generated from cutting stone etc. - See Also PPE
There werre no issues to report regarding power / distridbution.
Whilst not currnetly withing the John Sisk & Sons remit, the two remainaing buildings planned to be demolished / refrubished were being subject to a bat survey.
The use of enviropads / plant nappies / drip trays was evident throughout the site. Dewatering was also well managed although the pumps were not operating at the time of this visit.

A service trench had been left open to permit further cable pulling / service ducting. However, the barrier fencing was inadeuate, placed too close to the edge and the excavation was deep with no engineered batter or trench support installed.
sd1_potential_risk: Trench collapse causing injury / fatality & risk of persons falling into an open trench due to inadeuate barrier protection.
sd1_action: Discussed with Paul Greenwod at the time of the visit. Whilst there was no one owrking in the immediate area, the area was close to the road and footway. Paul Greenwood stated he would get the Black Hat for this work to undertake the necessary work to protect other on site. A coseout photo is now required.

sd1_observation: Vac-Ex machines were being used to expose existing and where required, newly laid services irrespective of the service being live or not. All activities for breaking ground were under a permit to work.
Suitable and sufficient fire extinguishers were observed around the site. It should be noted from previous reports that extinguishers should not be left outside in below zero tempartures.
Many areas of trip hazards cause by materials not being strored in a suitable loation.
sd1_action: John Sisk & Sons are to engage with the sub-contracto appointments and instigate a purge on housekeeping stardards.

sd1_observation: None observed at the time of the visit.
A sample observations of chains / slings etc were made and these provided to be colour tagged according to the John Sisk & Sons Ltd system.
in mostcases, mechanical handling of materials was onserved, where manual handling was observed, operaitves had use of kerb lifters etc and at the time of this visit no issues were observed.

See previous report 14.01.25 - evidence of closeout actions not provided. 
P&T Contracts operatives observed with ear protection worn of hoodies and beenie hats.
sd1_potential_risk: Breach of Legal Requirements - Potentiall FFI / Improvement Notice
sd1_action:
Provide evidence of Noise Risk Assessments. 
P&T Contracts to stop operatives wearing hoodies / beenie hats - this is bad practice - leads to misue of PPE.

sd1_observation: Good signage was being displayed around the site for mobile construction plant and delivery vehicles, however, signage for persons on foot was still lacking and no cautionary signage (raised rion work / trip hazards etc) had been afforded on roads and footways which were incomplete but in use. (see Access & Egress (Underfoot)
sd1_action: John Sisk & Sons Ltd are advised to risk assess access routes for persons on foot.

sd1_observation: The permit to dig covering the works in prohgress by P&T Contracts  carried the appproiate service drawing etc, but the pre-start brieging had not been completed or signed off. This is a sysytem designed to ensure those undertaking the works understand fully what if required of them.
sd1_action: John Sisk & Sons Ltd are to ensure that the sub-contract appointments fully understand the permit process. Those questioned  at the time of the visit were unaware.

sd1_observation: Those power tools observed appeared to be in good order, carried PAT in date.

Multiple operatives observed and challenged over wearing hoodies and beenie / wooly type hats under their hard hats.  The operative from P&T Contracts using the powercap whilst cutting stone had not repalced the lens cover of the mask making visibility low when using a stihl saw.
sd1_potential_risk: Potential risk of accidents from abusing PPE, not maintaining PPE / RPE designed to offer the user protection.
sd1_action: John Sisk & Sons Ltd are to check the conidition with powercap lens cover on receipe tof this report to ensure the contractor has repalced the lens.

sd1_observation: Section 278 works etc were controlled by an approved contractor with traffic light management in place and further two way raido communications mainatained.  However, it was again noticed that road pins were missing the protection caps which could lead to penetration injury.
sd1_potential_risk: Risk of injury to falling persons from open end steel pins.
sd1_action: Contractor to ensure that caps are fitted to the road pins as they are installed progressively and not install a row of pins and then go back after to fit the caps as others were working in the immediate area.

sd1_observation: Only one scaffolding on site enclosing and providing access to the silos.

Security Fencing not adeuate - does not meet HSG151 - S37 quote: A 2 m high fence is an effective site barrier for most sites, exceptions to this may be city centre sites and residential areas where there have been previous attempts by children to gain access to the site. In these cases larger hoardings may be appropriate. Perimeter fences can be constructed from a range of materials, including metal mesh. If a fence is to be used then it should be difficult to climb. Using a close mesh which prevents children getting their hands and feet through should mean that no one can gain handholds or footholds. Sectional fencing should be locked together and not easily separated without using a tool from the inside of the site. Note: close mesh fencing means climbing fencing is to be made difficult by the gap between the wires being 50mm. Many panels are 100mm wide and in addition they are not creating a 2m high barier. This issue was raised with Paul Greenwood in May 2025 around the Gate 2 works. It was reported t...
sd1_potential_risk: Easy un-authroised access to construction areas - risk to young children if access is gained.
sd1_action: I would advise that this type of water filled bollards and fecning be reveiwed.

sd1_observation: No issued observed during this visit. Temprary power from mobile generators poved the use of plant nappy's drip trays in use.

Site Perimeter Fencing - Previous report required copies of the Temporary Works Design details for permiter fencing. This has been provided along with a daily register of inspections but this has not included the Water Filled Barriers and Mesh Fencing.
sd1_potential_risk: Ease of access to construction areas for children etc. Barreiers are easy climb.
sd1_action: John Sisk & Sons Ltd need to undertake a further risk assessment on the type of site security fencing used to enclose construction areas. Details of how security will be provided should be included in the construction phase plan.

sd1_observation: Bollards were observed blocking a highlighted traffic route. This was questioned at the time of the visit and it was muted that a breifing had been given this monring advising teams of these changes. The signage observed could have easily been relocated prior to this briefing to further avoid confusion.
sd1_action: John Sisk & Sons Ltd need to walk the site and current traffic routes and amend / replace / provide suitable signage to compliment any chnages to the traffic management plan.

sd1_observation: See previous report 14.01.25 - evidence of closeout actions not provided.
sd1_potential_risk: Breach of Legal Requirements - Potentiall FFI / Improvement Notice
sd1_action: Provide evidence of HAV Risk Assessments

sd1_observation: Waste appeared to be well managed at the time of the visit. Several concrete washout cubes were also observed around the site.
Spot checks carried out on the main compound, the Zone 1 North Compound and an oasis unit during the visit. These inspectiosn provide to be compliant.
Work alongside the rail boundary was undertaken collaboratively with the assett owner.
General working at height was limited to accessing machines or silo's and at the time of this visit, there were no deep excavations observed and no ladder use observed.

Some footways were ice covered and other areas were covered in slippery mud and ponding has occurred in other areas making it difficult to see what you are walking across i.e. there could be objects under the water that may pose as a trip hazard. Paved and ashfelt coated roadways have raised ironwork and foot traps.
sd1_potential_risk: Slips/Trips & Falls causing related personal injuries.
sd1_action: Break down any ice-covered footways and slat or scrape clear. Muddy areas with the potential to cause slips need to be scrapped clear, stoned and recompact as necessary. Where routes have been obstructed, ensure that new routes are provided. Cover or adequately barrier traps in paving, place cone or barrier raised ironwork etc. Closout photograhaps are required.

sd1_observation:
Contained within the main body of this report are the floowing Breaches of the CDM Regualtions 
17.Safe places of construction work 
27.Traffic routes
28.Vehicles
29.Prevention of risk from fire, flooding or asphyxiation
30.Emergency procedures
31.Emergency routes and exits
32.Fire detection and fire-fighting
sd1_potential_risk: Potential for intervention by the enforcing authorities / accident and incidents
sd1_action:
Ensure suitable and sufficient closeout actions are taken to prevent;
1. Accidents
2. Injuries
3. Protesecution

sd1_observation: If the Ativity Risk Board are used in these morning breifings then these need to be update and dated.
sd1_action: Either update the baord if its being used or remove it.

sd1_observation: An operative who was delivering a dry mix of concrete for kerbing etc by mechanical pump and discharge chute. It was noticed that cementitious dust was being discharged into the atmosphere. The operative was not wearing any form of protection against inhalation of silica dust. When challenged he stated the employer provided masks but that it was upto the user to use it. (Breach of Regulation 10 of the PPE Regs) – Note operative was not clean shaven so the paper type issued are not suitable.
sd1_potential_risk: Inhalation of silica based dust with a potential for irreversible lung damage / cancer.
sd1_action: Contact be made with the supplier, request thier risk assessment for exposure to silica based dust and a record of PPE Issue and training including Face Fit Testing.

sd1_observation: Drip Tray / Plant Nappies not used to contain any potential uncontrolled spillages / leaks. The works undertaken by P&T Contracts alongside Leeman Road had a generator site to power the Clipper Saw and a canister of fuel immediately adjacent the generator.
sd1_potential_risk:
1. The Generator should be placed onto a Drip Tray / Enviropad / Plant Nappy to contain any spillages.
2. The Clipper Saw should be sat within a containment tray to control cut-off-slurry from entering the local surface water drains.
3. The Petrol Canister should be sat on a Enviropad / Plant Nappy to contain any spillages and should not be sat immediately adjacent a source of heat (the generator)
sd1_action:
1. A containment of the Clipper Saw is required. 
2. Petrol Canister needs to be relocated away from any source of heat/ignition and on a plant nappy.

sd1_observation: Good Ladder Access / Gas Montor lowered and suspended, and a Davit Arm installed. The entrant was not working in the excavation due to further excavation works currently being undertaken. A copy of the Temporary Works Design for the trench sheets were requested and provided for review. There were no further comments to make. A dewatering sump was also observed which lead to a discharge point where the bagging had a silt sock fitted.

Vacuum Excavators (Vac-Ex) are now being used to expose not only live services but also excavated down where previously laid service ducts have been installed but had no cables. This avoids damaging any ducting, minimises the risk of personal injury from hand digging etc.

This had been previously identified in the report dated 24th October 2024 and the closeout response from Sisk was "The extinguishers belong to PJ Edwards & not JN Piling. This contractor is not on site. The extinguishers have been moved to quarantine until they return to site" (Photo Two). Clearly a mistake as they were still on site at the time of this visit, had not been serviced and had been moved to another location? (Photo One)
sd1_potential_risk: Normally a Foam Fire Extinguishers should not be allowed to sit in temperatures lower than 4°C therefore, due to the recent low temperatures this extinguisher could fail and the CO2 Extinguishers had been tampered with as the trigger pin had been removed and may have partial discharge.
sd1_action:
Repalce / Service or as previusly suggested 'quaratine them'. The contractor must ensure where fire extinguishers that are to be stored outside are properly contained in a fire extinguisher box, cabinet or cover. Request a service engineer to check and replace any deteriorated parts to ensure the extinguishers remains pressurised and are corrosion free. 
A copy of the Fire Risk Assessment for the main office/compound is required for inspection.
sd1_owner: J Sisk & Sons Ltd / PJ Edwards

sd1_observation: No issues observed at the time of this report.

More raised walkways and roads surfaced to basecoat were being completed making access better however these are not marked / signed for general use but barrier segregations that were previously in place have been removed.
sd1_potential_risk: Slips/ Trips & Falls / Collision with moving plant / other vehicles.

sd1_observation: The operative using the pneumatic breaker wore banded ear defender but the two operatives working immediate to the noise exposure were checked and found to be using soft ear plugs. These not being fitted correctly suggesting poor training / poor attitude toward safety.  Another operative ware a body warmer over a High Visibility Top, he was challenged, he complied, then observed five minutes later doing the same). He was informed twice regarding the sites smoking policy.
sd1_potential_risk:
1. Risk of hearing damage due to incorrect use of PPE. 
2. Risk of not being seen by moving plant due to reflective strips on the High Visibility being covered.
sd1_action: Advise that the contractor provides training on the correct use of PPE (Hearing Protection).

sd1_observation: Only scaffolding on site at the time of the visit was the access scaffold for the silos
Water Lane generator was enclosed by Heras type fencing fitted with 'Acoustic Sound Pads' to minimise any environmental nuisance.

Four tipper lorries were observed reversing on site so they could be loaded with spoil for off-site removal. There were no vehicle marshals in place and none of the lorries had any working audible reversing alarms. I stopped one lorry driver and asked him to check the reversing alarm which did not sound. The driver was then requested that he reports the reversing alarm failures to his employer. (photo one)
sd1_potential_risk: It is a recognised industry hazard that serious injuries / fatalities have occurred by reversing vehicles on construction sites.
sd1_action: Instigate the use of Vehcile Masrhals until the pedestrain routes have been re-setablished in Zone One North. Provide a copy of the Traffic Management Plan including schematical drawing (all zones).

sd1_observation:
The relevant skips were appropriately signed for the user however: 
1. Skips that are designed to be closed, should be closed and not left open.
2. There is a wood skip but cardboard was placed in general waste? (the two are generally recycled in the same way and carboard is derived from wood)
3. Locally gerated waste could be better managed by the provision of mini skips to reduce localised build up of waste
sd1_potential_risk: Unnecessary Cost / Slips, Trips and Falls
sd1_action: Check with the appointed Waste Management company to ascertain if cardboard and wood can be mixed in the same skip.

sd1_observation: The site has a regular cleaning and maintenance regime in place for both the main compound facilities and for Zone One North. The smaller satellite (oasis units) around the site were managed locally but one unit was without running hot/warm water for hand washing and a supply of water for flushing the toilets. It is also worth an inspection of fuel levels for the generators to ensure that heating, lighting and pumps are working.
sd1_potential_risk: Whilst the overall condition of the welfare facilities on site was considered to be very good, this is technically a material breach of Schedule 2 of the CDM Regulations in CDM Zone 2 caused primarily by a lack of check/inspections locally.  Paul Greenwood advised that he would get the contractor to refil the water tanks. (It should be noted that a further oasis unit was available in Zone One South)
sd1_action: Water tanks to be re-filled to the Oasis Unit at Zone Two and a regime put in place to ensure all all other Oasis Units are compliant and functional.

sd1_observation:
Access to a deep trench was via a ladder platform and a secured ladder, however the ladder tag had been removed and when the entry operative was questions, he thought it would be laying on the ground somewhere. 
No other working height was observed although it was noted that the scaffold enclosing the silos has been maintained.
sd1_action: The access point should now be subject to re-inspection and the tag updated as necessary. This must also be updated on the temporary works register a copy of which is now requested as closeout evidence and a photo of the updated Ladder Tag.

sd1_observation: Designated footways mostly on concrete. Tracked area was slightly muddy but access limited to the groundworkers.
Both the CPP (dated Jan 2025) and TMP have been reveiwed and updated to refelct chnages to the scope of works and to relfect the new pedestrain routes and two new CDM work areas on site.
Work involving excavations including the road crossing is into made ground.
sd1_potential_risk: Soil contamination / buried ACM's (Asbestos Containing Materials)
sd1_action: Please provide a copy of the Site Investigation Report / Soil Sampling results for the new phase of works.

sd1_observation:
1. Site now has a desingated Coshh Locker.
2. Coshh Risk Assessments provided by subcontractors, in addition to Substance Data Sheets (SDS)
Operative observed dry sweeping the shared road removing mud/dust. The operative was not wearing a dust mask. Dry sweeping must be avoided unless dust mitigation controls are in place.
sd1_potential_risk: As this is a shared access road used by Heavy Goods Vehciles (HGVs) a better solution would be to use a road sweeper or Forklift with sweeper attachement thus removing the risk of the operative being hit by a moving vehicle and removes the risk of dust inhalation.
sd1_action:
1. Use a road sweeper
2. Operative to be Face Fit Tested and don a suitable mask (FFP3 Minimum)

sd1_observation: Distribution via spliter boex and power boxes observed. Cable management appeared ok at the time of the visit.
The excavation observed was approximatley 1m deep and 2m wide. Although was a mix of made ground it was considered that the risk of lower limb injuries was relative low.
Cable Avoidance equipment being progressively used during excavations, exposed services idendified.
The Policy Statements diplayed on the safety notice board were all out of date and were awating sign off by the three directors of Clegg.
sd1_potential_risk: Polices should be reveiwed at least anually.
sd1_action: Copies of all new policy statements to be updated and posted. Where ammendments to the Health & Safety Policy have been made, this must be made accessible to all employees.

sd1_observation: Generally given the tight confines of the site, it was felt at the time of the visit that housekeeping was being well managed.

New contractor on site 29.01.25 M3 Modular were actively progressing works on installing the Plain Construction Concrete (PCC) modular walls in the docking bay. There were signatures on their Risk Assessments and Method Statements (RAMs).
sd1_potential_risk: Operatives not following thier approved RAMS and working to thier own methods.
sd1_action: A full reveeiw of the RAMS needs to be made to ensure these are project specific / task relevant and then be acknowledged by the operatives undertaking the works.

sd1_observation: All statutory insurances displayed were in date.

On reveiew of the Lift Plan provided by M3 Modular, none of the operatives invloved have signed onto the lift plan. The lift plan details the a 30t excavaotr but the test cert included was for a 13t excavator. Only the Appointed Person (AP) was identified, it does not identify the Slinger/Signaller, the competence of the Machine Operator, Test Exam for the Chains or method of communication used.
sd1_potential_risk: Breach of the Lifting Operations and Lifting Equipment Regs, potential for failure.
sd1_action:
1. Ensure the Lift Plan has been reveiewed and approved. (provide evidence)
2. Ensure the competence of those invloved i.e.Plant Operator / Slinger Signaller (provide evidence)

sd1_observation: Operaitves were using a 4-wheel trolled to move composite wall sections bewteen the old and new extension. Telehandler used to transport blocks and other building materials minimising manual handling to a low level.
M3 Modular need to ensure they undertake and Noise Risk Assessment based of trigger times derieved from a Hand Arm Vibration Assessent.
sd1_potential_risk: Incorrect SNR (sound noise reduction) hearing protection afforded
sd1_action: Request copies of Nrisk Risk Assessments

sd1_observation: There were two forklifts on site with both  having the seat belt clipped across the seat proving abuse of a safety system.  This is a repetative observation.
sd1_action:
1. Undertake regular spot checks on all plant operators
2. Re-brief plant operators on the requirement for using seat belts by a Toolbox talk) (TBT)
3. Provide evidence of TBT.

sd1_observation: There was only one portable power tool observed at the time of the visit. A battery powered drill (not in use) but appears to be in good visual order.

Generally all site workers were complying with the sites and clients PPE and FPE (Fall Prevention Equipment) while using the scissor lift (Schneider requirement). Note, this does not remove the corrective action for Noise)

Although not in use, the edge protection appears to have gaps greater that 470mm and given the recent weather conditions on a sloping roof, an intermetiate rail between the roof surface and edge protection is strongly advised.  Given the recurring issues with inadequate edge protection, it may be prudent to re-assess the competence of the contractor responsible for its instalation.
sd1_action:
1. Strike scaffolding and edge protection (when weather permits) if no longer required.
2. If further access for roofing works is required, re-assess the edge protection and close the gap between the roof and intermetiate rail.

sd1_observation: The Site Offices/Canteens etc are due an anual test in February - advise booking this in now.
There is a traffic light system in place due to the current excavation / road crossing. Good signage also observed.
M3 Modular have provided a HSE HAV assessment which was incomplete. Therefore exposure not correctly assessed.
sd1_potential_risk: Operatives may be over exposed to HAV.
sd1_action: M3 Modular must adequatley assess the exposure to ensure operaives are not exposed to excessive use of plant/equipment over the daily exposure limit.

sd1_observation: Good standards of welfare facilities have been provided. Check running hot/warm water, hand wshing sopas and barrier creams and facilties to dry hands. Seperate Male/Female toilets. Canteen was clean.

1. There were no operaitves working on the roof at the time of the visit, but it must be noted that access to the composite roof must be denied during freezing terperatures to remove the potential for slips and falls on sloping roofs. 
2. Unsafe use of a MEWP (Scissor Lift) - Operaitve positioned in an unsafe zone / potential for both falls and crushing hazard.
3. Stabilser Legs are not grounded to prevent basket sway
sd1_potential_risk: Slips, Falls, Crusing, Instability of Elevated Scissor Lift.
sd1_action: Stop work and re-instruct the cladding contractors on safety in the use of Mobile Elelvating Work Platforms.

sd1_observation: Trip hazard created by fencing panel foot blocks, narrow walkways and trip hazards. The pedestrain roues as discussed on site need to be sufficiently wide enough (900mm) and clear of obstructions to minimise trips when used either under normal contitions or in the event of an emergency. This was not the case on site and pedestrian routes were badly sign posted or routes led to dead ends. Operatives were observed walking across the completed areas (handed back to the client) used by heavy goods / distribution vehicles.
sd1_potential_risk: Slips Trips & Falls and associated potential injury / collision with moving vehicles.
sd1_action: Re-route foot personel routes to provide a clear, signed and sufficiantly wide enough throughfare. Where these cross traffic routes, gated barriers are to be used, typical signage such as 'Thumbs Up' look both ways etc to be provided.

sd1_observation:
Material Breaches of the CDM Regulations. Contained within the main body of this report are the following Breaches of the CDM Regulations:
17.Safe places of construction work 
27.Traffic routes
28.Vehicles
31.Emergency routes and exits
sd1_potential_risk:
Ensure suitable and sufficient closeout actions are taken to prevent; 
1. Accidents 
2. Injuries 
3. Prosecution
sd1_action: The traffic routes  are firmly established however, pedestrian routes were lacking control - some routes led to deadends, created hazards by persons on foot crossing the clients delivery route, footways being too narrow and with trip hazards.

sd1_observation: There is a good record of Toolbx Talks being undertaken.

Suitable storage facilities were provided on site, contractor steel storage containers were on site. Note: Where flammables are being stored in these containers, the fire extinguisher points need to be located where they are easily accessible.

There were no activities creating hazardouos dust exposure at the time of the visit. The road saw was not in use and the stihl saw was used to cut steel mesh.  As previously noted: ensure those exposed to hazarduos dust must be clean shaven if using dispoable / half mask type FFP3 masks or are issued with a power-cap airlflow type RPE kit.

The compound and site cabins have been re-located since the last visit. These are now connected to a main supply however, the cabins need to be re-tested but no certificate was posted next to the fuse baords. As for any electrical installation, a mobile or transportable unit must be inspected and tested before being put into service to verify, so far as is reasonably practicable, that the requirements of the Regulations have been met (Regulation 641.1 refers) BS7671
sd1_action: In view of this, it is essential that the full details of the work covered by the certi?cate, including the limitations on the electrical testing, are accurately recorded on the Electrical Installation Certi?cate (EIC). The results of continuity and insulation resistance, together with the results of the inspection, provide evidence that the circuits have been installed in accordance with the relevant requirements of BS 7671.

sd1_observation: There were issues noted at the time of this visit.
Excavations were either shallow or covered over with road plates (see further comments)
Existing services which had been exposed with protected using road plates.

External Fire Points containing fire extinguishers were not in enclosed units. Normally a Foam Fire Extinguishers should not be allowed to sit in temperatures lower than 4°C therefore, due to the recent low temperatures this extinguisher could fail.
sd1_potential_risk: The fire extinguishers located outside my fail when required in the event of an emergency.
sd1_action: It is advised that fire extinguishers are stored in an enclosed fire extinguihser cabinet.

sd1_observation: Policy was in date and posted
A cross check was made with two operatives proving the induction system was being well managed.
All posted and holding a valid period of cover. The notice boards were yet to be posted floowing the relocation of the site compound area and cabins etc.

Lighting inside the new shed was deemed to be sufficient for cable tray works howver, it should be noted that where work required perception to detail is required, additional lighting should be provided. (Some Electrcians were noted with head torches)

A spot check was made on two MEWPS and these were found to be withing service date. The Permit system in use was also noted and cross references to the induction / training records and test exam certs.
At the time of this visits, there were no manual handling issues observed. There was a Forklift Truck availalbe for the movement of materials.
As per provious reports, sub-contractor appointments are not undertaking adequate noise risk assessments, ensuring that hearing protection afforded is suitable for the user.
sd1_potential_risk: Material Breach of Regualtion 5 the Noise at Work Regulations  (The Control of Noise at Work Regulations 2005) require that an assessment of the risks from noise at work is made and that (a) legal limits on noise exposure are not exceeded and (b) action is taken if necessary to reduce the noise exposure that produces the risk. Long term exposure may lead to Noise Induced Hearing Loss.
sd1_action: Sub-contractors are required undertake Noise Risk Assessments to ensure exposure is reduced, elimited or controlled.

sd1_observation: Main issues are around the emergency escape route signage and pedestrian management signage as detailed elsewhere in this report.
sd1_potential_risk: Confusion in emergncy situations / unsafe pedestrian crossing points.
sd1_action: Provide photo of re-routed pedestrain routes and signage as discussed.

sd1_observation: There is a good system for permits however, it was noted that the hot works permit from 03.03.25 had not been closed out correctly and the 1hr fire check not observed. In addition the MEWP Permit 03.03.25 had not covered its operatorsw pre-user inspection.
sd1_action: Re-breif sub contractors on the permit process as necessary - undertake periodic checks to ensure the process in being followed.

sd1_observation: Mobile plant usch as MEWPS were now located next to the compound but it is remcommended that this area be enclosed withfnecing as a defined CDM area. Other plant (360 track excavators had been subject to thier statutory inspections and service regimes.
sd1_potential_risk: Open areas shared with the client need to be fenced off to prevent unauthired entry.

sd1_observation: Most powertools were battery operated type. There were 110v distribution boxes and cables inside the unit avalble for power tools. Battery powered drill / drivers were noted holstered however these were not teathered with a tool lanyard by those working at height (MEWPS).
sd1_potential_risk: Tools falling onto persons below / risk of personal injury.
sd1_action: Contractors must adequatley risk assess wotking at heights and include within that assessment to potential risk of falling tools / materials etc. When working at heights, inside Mobile Elevating Working Platforms (MEWPS) all tools should be tethered to a tool lanyard or the immediate area below barrerd off to provent those on the ground entering a hazard area.

sd1_observation: All trades on site appeared to be observing the site rules for wearing PPE, however, the practice of wearing beenie hats (wooly) or hoodies under the hard hat needs to be condemed. A safety helmet should be worn pointing to the front and firmly placed on your head with the nape strap adjusted so the safety helmets fits securley. The safety harness must not be twisted or loose. If you wear a thick winter hat or hoodie under your hard hat, it will prevent the harness from fitting securely, thus reducing the effectiveness in protecting your head. To ensure you are safety compliant, a worker should instead seek out compatible options such as manufacturer approved head or helmet warmers and liners as a safe alternative.
sd1_potential_risk: When wearing a thick winter hat or hoodie under a safety helmet, the space created between your head and the hard hat will decrease stability. The hard hat could potentially shift or slip during movement or on impact, which could affect the fields of vision and increase the risk of a potential accidents.
sd1_action: Advise a toolbox talk breifing be given. In addition, the employers must provide suitable (purpose designed) liners for winter working.

sd1_observation: The Scaffolder RAMS afforded copies of TG20 Compliance Sheets - however the RAMS state either tube and fitting or cuplock system scaffold. (Note also the scaffold RAMS refer the project as RPC Ltd?
sd1_potential_risk: It must be noted that TG20 does not cover the use of System Scaffolding and that should be erected in accordance with the manufacturers design. In addition, Clegg Group should speficy what they require under temporary works. Sysytem scaffold may leave gaps etc that tube and fitting scaffold can avoid.
sd1_action: Specify the type of scaffolding required - ensure RAMS are specific to the site and nature of the planned works. Ensure a Scaffold Handover certificate is provided and note: the statutory duty for ensuring scaffold inspections take place comes from Regulation 12 of the Work at Height Regulations 2005, and this rests with Clegg Group Ltd as the end user. Typically, the individual who accepts the handing over certificate holds that duty. It is not adviseable to allow self regualtion.

sd1_observation: Steel Road Plates used over service crossing. This is classed as temporary works and therefore require a design and should be placed on the tempoary works register.
sd1_potential_risk: Inadequate strenght of road plate, movement of road plate (not fixed down) risk to vehicles crossing the service duct.
sd1_action: Provide a copy of the temprary works design and register.

sd1_observation: Site security is managed by Schneider and controlled entry into the site by both vehciles and persons on foot.
See comment on electrical distribution & testing.

Many Sub-Contractors appointed have poor content in thier RAMS, in particular reference is ade to the lack of risk assessments for noise, vibration, selection of work equipment etc. Many documents contain open statements such as 'suitable PPE' and do not directly adrress the hazards by affording detailed control measures. Any PPE required must be assessed for its suitablility and provided to the Sub-contractors employees / LOSC. This has placed the site manager for Clegg Group in a postiion where he is now trying to sort out the Hand Arm Vibration and Noise Assessments on behalf of the sub-contractors. It must be noted the the sub-contractors have a legal duty to comply with Regulation 7 of the Managrment of Health & Safety at Work Regulations and cannot negate that duty.
sd1_potential_risk: The site manager has not recieved any formal training in undertaking Noise or HAV assessments but was making attempts to be compliant.
sd1_action: Sub-contractors must enage the services of a person who is competent to assist them in complying with Health & Safety Legislation. It is not the Prinicpal Contractors duty to do these, they should 'Plan. Manage and Monitor'

sd1_potential_risk: Site needs to estalish that all temporary works are suitable and meet the requirements of thier intended use.
sd1_action: A full reveeiw of the temprary works is advised.

sd1_observation: Traffic Management was not being managed collaboratively with Schneider. Routes were poorly signed, obsructed and had blind spots.
sd1_potential_risk: Colissions / Risk of Serious Injury to foot peronell.
sd1_action: Advise a collaborative meeting with the depot manage and Schneider H&S Manager to ensure safe roues are maintained including pedestrian routes.

sd1_observation: As per provious reports, sub-contractor appointments are not undertaking adequate Hand Arm Vibrations risk assessments, ensuring that operatives are not over exposed.
sd1_potential_risk: Vibration White Finger / Carpul Tunel loss of feeling in the digits, pain in the forearms etc. Material Breach of Regualtion 5 & 6 the Noise at Vibtration at Regulations 2005.
sd1_action: Sub contractors to undertake aprrporiate assessments and log the results. Ntoe: The site manager was progressing making a record on equipment on site and both the magnitude rating and Noise Levels which was good to see, but he should receive training.

sd1_observation: Wastes aring from the works on site appeared well managed. Skips were being provided on site.
Welfare provisions were deemed to be suitable for the numbers on site (18 inc one two females). A toaster has now been purchased (new) for the office. Note: a fire blanket is to be provided.
No Scaffolding but MEWPs were being used to access high level working areas.
No consultation process, not TBT's Morning Breifings, RAMS not disseminated to the workforce.
sd1_action: Stop work; bring the teams in and undertake breifing sessions.

sd1_observation: The site was on fire at the time of the visit
All respective First Aid Facilities Including a Defibrilator Unit have been provided.
Policy has not been updated since 2008
sd1_potential_risk: Policy does not incorporate new and superceded regualtions.
sd1_action: The PC must fully reveiw and update thier Company H&S Policy with immeidate affect and reveiw anually.
